name: Transaction
overview:
This class allows you interact with Cloud Spanner.

First, install @google-cloud/spanner with npm:

$ npm install --save @google-cloud/spanner

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to @google-cloud/spannerâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Compute Engine

var spanner = require('@google-cloud/spanner')();

Elsewhere

var spanner = require('@google-cloud/spanner')({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to @google-cloud/spanner are outlined in our Authentication guide.

methods.name: Transaction
methods.description:
Use a Transaction object to read and write against inside of your Cloud Spanner database.

This object is created and returned from database/runTransaction.

params.name: options.exactStaleness
params.description: • Executes all reads at the timestamp that is exactStaleness old.

params.name: options.minReadTimestamp
params.description: • Executes all reads at a timestamp greater than or equal to this. This option can only be used for single-use transactions.

params.name: options.maxStaleness
params.description: • Read data at a timestamp that is greater than or equal to this. This option can only be used for single-use transactions.

params.name: options.readTimestamp
params.description: • Execute all reads at the given timestamp.

params.name: options.strong
params.description: • Read at the timestamp where all previously committed transactions are visible.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: rollback
methods.description: Roll back a transaction, releasing any locks it holds. It is a good idea to call this for any transaction that includes one or more queries that you decide not to commit.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: run
methods.description:
Execute a SQL statement on this database inside of a transaction.

Performance Considerations

This method wraps the streaming method, spanner/transaction#run for your convenience. All rows will be stored in memory before being released to your callback. If you intend on receiving a lot of results from your query, consider using the streaming method, so you can free each result from memory after consuming it.

examples.caption: The SQL query string can contain parameter placeholders. A parameter placeholder consists of '@' followed by the parameter name.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: runStream
methods.description: Create a readable object stream to receive resulting rows from a SQL statement.

examples.caption: The SQL query string can contain parameter placeholders. A parameter placeholder consists of '@' followed by the parameter name.
If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

methods.name: end
methods.description: Let the client know you're done with a particular transaction. This should only be called for read-only transactions.

methods.name: createReadStream
methods.description: Create a readable object stream to receive rows from the database using key lookups and scans.

examples.caption: Rows are returned as an array of object arrays. Each object has a name and value property. To get a serialized object, call toJSON().
If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: query.columns
params.description: • The columns of the table to be returned for each row matching this query.

params.name: query.keys
params.description: • The primary keys of the rows in this table to be yielded.

params.name: query.index
params.description: • The name of an index on the table.

examples.caption: If you are using a Promise to retrieve the transaction.

params.name: keys
params.description: • The keys for the rows to delete.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: insert
methods.description: Insert rows of data into this table.

examples.caption: Multiple rows can be inserted at once.
If you are using a Promise to retrieve the transaction.

params.name: keyVals
params.description: • A map of names to values of data to insert into this table.

methods.name: read
methods.description: Performs a read request against the specified Table.

examples.caption: Rows are returned as an array of object arrays. Each object has a name and value property. To get a serialized object, call toJSON().
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: query
params.description: • Configuration object, describing what to read from the table.

params.name: query.columns
params.description: • The columns of the table to be returned for each row matching this query.

params.name: query.keys
params.description: • The primary keys of the rows in this table to be yielded.

params.name: query.index
params.description: • The name of an index on the table.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.rows
params.description: • Rows are returned as an array of object arrays. Each object has a name and value property. To get a serialized object, call toJSON().

methods.name: replace
methods.description: Replace rows of data within a table.

examples.caption: If you are using a Promise to retrieve the transaction.

params.name: keyVals
params.description: • A map of names to values of data to insert into this table.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: update
methods.description: Update rows of data within a table.

examples.caption: If you are using a Promise to retrieve the transaction.

params.name: keyVals
params.description: • A map of names to values of data to insert into this table.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: upsert
methods.description: Insert or update rows of data within a table.

examples.caption: If you are using a Promise to retrieve the transaction.

params.name: keyVals
params.description: • A map of names to values of data to insert into this table.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.
